entry.title: Developing an HTTP Client in Go: From Installation to First Requests
entry.summary: In this 27-min read article, we will help developers who are new to Go and REST APIs build their first HTTP client. We will start with the basics and progress to more advanced topics, such as sending different types of HTTP requests, handling responses, and automating requests. Additionally, we will explore practical examples and best practices to help you create secure and reliable HTTP clients. https://hostman.com/tutorials/developing-an-http-client-in-go/

entry.title: Fix It in Design or Fight It in Production ‚Äî Your Call
entry.summary: Fixing a bug in prod can cost up to 100x more than fixing it during design. Wild, right? But it happens all the time. Someone makes a tiny assumption in a planning session. A Jira ticket doesn‚Äôt get enough context. No one questions the edge cases. And then‚Ä¶ that ‚Äúminor‚Äù detail shows up in prod. Now it‚Äôs a full-blown issue, breaking user flows, burning dev hours, and dragging in the whole team for an emergency fix. By the time it‚Äôs caught, it‚Äôs not just a bug. It‚Äôs a cost center. Not just for engineering, but for support, for ops, for customer trust. Planning isn‚Äôt just about timelines. It‚Äôs your first and best chance to save your team from costly mistakes down the road. So you better do it right. The earlier you catch the gaps, the cheaper they are. And the less your engineers want to scream into a pillow üòÖ

entry.title: Side Project Deployment: From Hours of Pain to a Single Command?
entry.summary:
From docker-compose up to Live on a VPS
Hey DEV community! We all love that feeling of building something new ‚Äì a side project, a small tool, maybe the beginnings of a startup. docker-compose up hums along perfectly on our local machine, and life is good. Then comes the moment we want to share it with the world, or even just access it reliably ourselves: deployment. For me, this was often where the fun slowed down and the headaches began. When it's time to move beyond localhost, we typically look at a few routes: Examples: Heroku, Render, Fly.io, Netlify Pros: Simplicity ‚Äî often just a git push to production Handles infra, basic scaling, and boilerplate Cons: Can get expensive as you grow Limited control May not support complex Docker Compose setups Examples: DigitalOcean, Linode, Hetzn‚Ä¶

entry.title: Harnessing Secure Configuration Management with Vault for MERN and Beyond
entry.summary:
Modern application development involves handling sensitive credentials‚ÄîAPI keys, database passwords, encryption keys, cloud tokens, and more. Traditionally, many engineering teams manage these secrets using .env files checked into CI/CD pipelines or shared manually across environments. While easy to set up, this approach creates serious security and operational risks.
Vault, particularly HashiCorp Vault, is a robust solution to this problem. It provides a central, secure, and auditable system for managing secrets using pluggable secret engines and dynamic access controls. Vault has been widely adopted across industries for securing configurations in both small projects and large enterprise systems.
While .env files are convenient for development, they come with major limitations: Insecur‚Ä¶

entry.title: Unleash your idea: Building a landing page
entry.summary: At the start of this week I launched the landing page for Velocity Pilot as a first step in launching the tool. I wanted to explain some of the thinking that went into this which would be useful for anyone else who has an idea they want to unleash on the world! As an engineer it's probably tempting to crank out some static website using a bunch of front end tooling but I wanted to keep this as simple as possible. I decided to use a SaaS tool for the landing page and for gathering sign up details from people. The landing page has two purposes: Explain and showcase the idea behind Velocity Pilot Get interested people to sign up to a closed beta I decided to keep the page short and simple with a large hero image that displays a mockup for the tool. ChatGPT helped with this and I created a moc‚Ä¶

entry.title: Curating the Best No-Code Tools of 2025 ‚Äì Introducing Awesome No-Code Tools
entry.summary:
Hey Dev Community! I'm Steve, an indie dev who loves building things and finding smarter ways to ship ideas fast. Lately, I've been diving deep into the no-code space ‚Äî not just as a developer, but as a curious builder exploring what‚Äôs possible without writing a single line of code. To make sense of it all (and help others too), I started a GitHub repo: üëâ Awesome No-Code Tools It's a curated collection of the 100+ best no-code tools in 2025, organized by category, use case, and platform. If you're launching a startup, prototyping an idea, or just curious ‚Äî there's something here for you. Some categories include: Website & App Builders Automation Tools AI-Powered No-Code Databases VR ...and more being added regularly! While I still write code daily, I see no-code as an accelerator ‚Äî a way to validate ideas, save time, and help non-developers to vibe code. The line between "developer" and "builder" is blurring, and that‚Äôs exciting. If you know a killer tool that deserves to be on the list, feel free to: Open a pull request
Drop a suggestion in issues
Community-curated = community strong üí™ I‚Äôd love to hear what no-code tools you can‚Äôt live without in 2025. Drop a comment below or star the repo if you find it helpful üåü

entry.title: How to Prompt Veo 3?
entry.summary: I‚Äôm thrilled to dive into Veo 3, Google DeepMind‚Äôs groundbreaking AI video generation model. Over the past week, Veo 3 has dominated headlines, social feeds, and creative conversations. From satirical reels roasting influencer culture to mock pharmaceutical ads that feel startlingly real, creators and marketers alike are experimenting with Veo 3‚Äôs uncanny ability to translate text prompts into polished, cinematic video clips complete with dialogue, sound effects, and music ([The Economic Times][1], [Axios][2]). In this article, I‚Äôll walk you through Veo 3‚Äôs core features, its current applications, how you can get started, and best practices for crafting prompts that yield spectacular results. Veo 3 is Google‚Äôs cutting-edge AI video generation model, first unveiled at Google I/O 2025. Build‚Ä¶

entry.title: üß†Writing Developer-Friendly Content That Performs: Why You Should Care About SEO (and a Checklist to Help)
entry.summary: Whether you're writing a tutorial on Docker, sharing a bug fix in a JavaScript library, or publishing your first open-source walkthrough ‚Äî writing on Dev.to is about sharing knowledge, growing as a creator, and helping the wider developer community. But there‚Äôs something we often overlook in technical writing: ‚úÖ How we write can be just as important as what we write. That‚Äôs where SEO for developer content comes in ‚Äî not as a marketing gimmick, but as a way to make sure the work you publish actually reaches the people who need it. Let‚Äôs unpack this. üß© Why Should Developers Care About SEO? Here‚Äôs why SEO matters for developers: üîç Searchability ‚Äî Your solution to a common error could save someone hours‚Ä¶ if it‚Äôs findable. üåç Reach ‚Äî SEO-optimized posts rank better on Google, Stack Overflow, ‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to Deploy a Full Stack App to Koyeb Using Docker Compose and GitHub Actions
entry.summary: When building full-stack applications with Docker Compose, it‚Äôs essential to have a reliable way to ship and deploy both frontend and backend services in sync. This article walks through setting up a CI/CD pipeline using GitHub Actions to deploy a multi-container Docker application to Koyeb, a modern platform that supports containerized workloads out of the box. We‚Äôll use a real project‚Äîcomplete with frontend, backend, and supporting services‚Äîas our base. The focus here isn‚Äôt just deployment, but doing it cleanly and automatically through GitHub Actions. You‚Äôll see how to: Prepare your application with Docker Compose Configure GitHub Actions workflows for CI and deployment Push both services to Koyeb in a unified pipeline By the end of this guide, you‚Äôll have a production-grade deployment ‚Ä¶
